required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Influence of Wrist Taping on Handgrip Strength in Crossfit Athletes
clinical_study.official_title: Influence of Wrist Taping on Handgrip Strength in Crossfit Athletes - Crossover Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The idea that the use of a wristband can increase the grip strength is old, but without systematic scientific evidence. Most Crossfit practitioners wear wrist bands during training because it is believed that the wristband increases the grip strength of the hand. The aim of this study is to to analyze the influence of the use of the wristband on the maximum force value and on the dynamic resistance of hand hold. A simple blind randomized cross-over trial will be performed.

primary_outcome.description: Mean of the first 3 hand pressures (kg) measured by hand dynamometer

secondary_outcome.description: Percentage (%) of strength measured in the last 3 movements in relation to the first 3 movements

arm_group.description: Performs the first round of test with the sham comparator than with the experimental wrist taping
Performs the first round of test with the experimental wrist taping than with the sham comparator

intervention.description: Wrist taping as used as standard in CrossFit practice

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- be an amateur practitioner of the Crossfit modality with at least 6 months of regular sports practice (at least 4 times a week)
- between 18-40 years old
- agree to participate in the study and sign the informed consent form (ICF).
Exclusion Criteria:
- active wrist/ arm injury or pain on the day of the test (pain score greater than 3 in 10 for both shoulder, forearm, wrist and / or hand on the VAS pain scale)
- history of wrist injury (especially fracture or ligament injury)
- previous wrist surgery
